Section on Divine Anomalies, Part 2: Jianta Le, 1; Hala Jie, 2
Jianta Le was originally from the Western Regions and had been in Luoyang for many years.
Although the assembly respected his conduct, they still could not fathom him.
Later, he told the monks:
To the southeast of Luoyang, there is Panchi Mountain. There used to be an ancient temple site there, and the foundation still remains. We can build together.
The assembly did not believe him, so they went to investigate.
Entering the mountain, they reached a place with flat ground on all sides. Le pointed and said:
This is the foundation of the temple.
They dug and indeed found the stone foundation of the temple below.
Later, he pointed out the location of the lecture hall and monks' quarters, and it was all verified as he said.
The assembly was all amazed and then built together, making Le the abbot of the temple.

The temple was over 100 li away from Luoyang City. Every morning, he would go to the temples in Luoyang for the midday meal, and in the evening, he would beg for a bowl of oil to return to the temple to light the lamps.
He took this as his regular practice and never failed.
There was a person who was good at walking and wanted to follow Le to observe his slow and fast pace. He ran and sweated, always suffering from not being able to keep up.
Le told him to hold the corner of his robe. He only heard the sound of a strong wind and no longer felt tired. In a short while, they arrived at the temple.
Later, Le's whereabouts were unknown.
He Rujie He Rujie was originally from Fan Yang.
He left home at a young age and recited scriptures of 2 million words.
His nature was profound and mysterious, and he upheld the precepts with integrity. He had a beautiful appearance.
He often practiced dhuta and stayed alone in the mountains and wilderness.
In the ninth year of Tai Kang of Emperor Wu of the Jin Dynasty, he temporarily arrived in Luoyang. At that time, there was a severe epidemic, and people died one after another.
He Rujie used spells to cure them, and eight or nine out of ten recovered.
In the first year of Yuankang of Emperor Hui of the Jin dynasty, he went west and stayed in a stone chamber on Mount Louzhi to sit in meditation.
This chamber was far from water, so people wanted to open a stream for him.
Jie said:
You don't need to trouble yourselves.
He then rose and kicked the stone wall to the west of the chamber with his left foot, and the wall collapsed and his foot sank in.
When he pulled his foot out, water flowed out from it, clear, fragrant, and soft, never ceasing in the four seasons.
Those who came to drink it all stopped feeling hungry and thirsty, and cured illnesses.
In the eighth year of Yuankang, he sat upright and passed away. His disciples cremated him according to the Western method.
They burned him for many days, but his body still sat in the fire, the water not turning to ashes, so they moved him back to the stone chamber.

Later, a person from the Western Regions named Zhu Dingzi An Shi went to that country during the Xianhe period of the Jin dynasty and personally observed it. The body was still sitting upright, already for more than thirty years.
Ding later arrived in the capital and transmitted it to the secular people.
3 Zhu Faxui Zhu Faxui was originally from Guanzhong.
He was upright and had a sense of moral discipline. He entered Mount Song and served Futu Mi as his teacher.
In the first year of the Jianyuan era of Emperor Kang of the Jin dynasty, he arrived in Xiangyang and stayed at Yang Shuzizi Temple.
He did not accept separate invitations. Whenever he went begging for food, he would carry a rope bed with him. If he encountered a secluded and open road, he would set it up and sit there.
Sometimes he would encounter rain, and he would cover himself with an oiled robe.
When the rain stopped, people would only see the rope bed and not know where Faxui was.
Before they could finish searching, Faxui would already be on the bed.
He often told his disciple Fazhao:
In your past life, you broke a chicken's leg. The retribution will soon come.
Soon after, Fazhao was thrown by someone and his leg was permanently injured.
Later, he told his disciples:
There is an old man in Xinye whose life is about to end. I want to save him.
He still walked between the furrows, and sure enough, he saw a man leading an ox to plow the field.
Hui begged the man for the ox, but the man did not give it. Hui went forward and grabbed the ox's nose himself. The man feared he was unusual, so he finally gave it to him.
Hui led the ox and made a vow, then returned it to the man after seven steps.
The man died a few days later.
Later, Yu Zhigong, the General Who Pacifies the West, garrisoned Xiangyang. He had never revered the Dharma, and heard that Hui had extraordinary abilities, so he was very jealous of him.
Hui predicted to his disciples in advance:
My karmic retribution will soon arrive. I admonish my relatives to diligently cultivate blessings and goodness.
Two days later, he was indeed arrested and executed, at the age of fifty-eight.
Before he died, he told the people:
Three days after my death, there will be a violent rainstorm.
Sure enough, on the appointed day, there was a great flood, and the water in the city gates was ten feet deep. Many residents were swept away and drowned, and there were many deaths.
At that time, there was a man named Fan Cai from Langzhong, Bazhong.
He was originally a monk who sold divination in the market of Hedong. He walked barefoot, wore tattered clothes, and had the same attire in winter and summer. His words were often prophetic.
Later, he left the monastic life and became a layperson, practicing the teachings of Zhang Lu.
An Huize, An Huize, unknown clan.
He was not consistent in his youth, but he was extraordinary and different from others. He was good at calligraphy and eloquent.
During the Yongjia period of the Jin dynasty, the world was plagued by an epidemic. Huize prayed day and night, wishing the divine beings to bestow medicine to cure the people.
One day, he went out of the temple gate and saw two stones shaped like jars. Huize suspected they were unusual objects.
He picked them up and looked inside, and sure enough, there was divine water inside.
Those who drank it were all cured.
Later, he stayed at Dashishi Temple in Luoyang. He personally wrote the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra in fine calligraphy on yellow silk, making it into one scroll.
The characters were like small beans, yet they were clearly recognizable, totaling more than ten copies.
He gave one copy to Hu Mu, the wife of Zhou Zhongzhi of Runan, for worship.
When Hu Mu crossed the river, she brought the sutra with her. Later, she was caught in a disastrous fire and had to leave the sutra behind in a hurry. She grieved and lamented.
After the fire was extinguished, she found it in the ashes.
The cover and binding were not damaged at all.
Those who witnessed this at the time all turned away from evil and changed their beliefs.
This sutra is now in the possession of Nun Shou at Jianjing Temple in the capital.
At that time, there was also Kang Huichi in Luoyang.
It is said that he too had spiritual powers and was able to communicate with the divine.
Shi Shi Shi Shi was a person from the Western Regions.
He lived in solitude and ate air, not consuming the five grains. He could travel five hundred li a day.
His predictions of future events were as accurate as if he were pointing to his palm.
In the twelfth year of Jianyuan of Fu Jian, he arrived in Chang'an.

He could use secret spells to summon divine dragons. Whenever there was a drought, Jian would always request him to summon the dragon with spells. Soon, the dragon would descend into the bowl, and the sky would immediately rain heavily.
Jian and the ministers would personally go to the bowl to observe it, all marveling at its strangeness.
Jian revered him as the nation's deity, and the common people all bowed down to him, from then on there was no more worry about scorching droughts.
In the twelfth month of the sixteenth year, he passed away without illness. Jian wept for him with deep grief.
Seven days after his death, Jian, considering his spiritual extraordinariness, tried to open the coffin to see. He did not see the corpse anywhere, only the shroud remained.
In the seventeenth year, from the first month until the sixth month, it did not rain.
Jian reduced his meals and removed his ornaments to welcome the harmonious qi. In the seventh month, it rained.
Jian said to the Secretariat Director Zhu Rong:
If Shi Gong were here, how could I be so anxious about the clouds and the Han?
Is this master a great sage?ğŸ”½Rong said:
Yes.
This technique is profound and distant, indeed a marvel of the ancient past.
Shi Tanhuo, Shi Tanhuo, it is unknown where he was from.
He ate vegetables and practiced asceticism, always staying in cemeteries and under trees, specializing in using spiritual powers to transform people.
At that time, the Xiongnu of Hexi, Toufa Lilu, usurped power in Xiping and called himself king, naming the year Jianhe.
In the second year of Jianhe, the eleventh month, Tanhuo came from Henan to Xiping, holding a tin staff, and had people kneel before it, saying:
This is the eye of prajÃ±Ä. If you revere it, you can attain the Way.
People gave him clothes and other things, which he accepted but then threw on the ground or released into the river.
After a while, the clothes would return to their original owners, not soiled at all.
He walked as fast as the wind. Those who tried to chase him were always exhausted and could not catch up.
He spoke of people's life and death, nobility and humbleness, with not a hair's breadth of error.
People sometimes hid his staff, and Huo would close his eyes for a short while and immediately know where it was. Everyone marveled at his supernatural abilities, but no one could fathom them.
However, there were many who followed Buddhism because of him.
Lu Gu had a younger brother, Nutan, who was given the title of Cavalry General, and his power rivaled that of the pseudo-state.
He was suspicious by nature and harmed many people.
Huo often told Tan:
You should cultivate goodness and practice the Way, serving as a bridge for future generations.
Tan said:
Since ancient times, I have respectfully served Heaven, Earth, famous mountains, and great rivers.
Now if I suddenly follow Buddhism, I fear it would go against the intentions of my ancestors.
If you can go seven days without eating and your complexion remains the same, then Buddhism is indeed divine. I will follow it.
So he had people secretly guard him for seven days, and Huo showed no signs of hunger or thirst.
Tan sent the monk Zhixing to secretly bring cakes to Huo, who said:
How can I deceive others? Deceive the king?
Dan deeply admired him and greatly increased his respect. Because of this, he changed his faith and abstained from killing, promoting kindness.
The people of the country, having received his blessings, all called him the Great Master.
When he entered or left the streets, the common people all welcomed him and paid homage to him.
Dan had a daughter who was very seriously ill. He invited Huo to save her life.
Huo said:
Life and death are determined by fate, even the sages cannot change it, how could I be able to prolong life?
I can only tell you when it will happen.
Dan insisted on asking.
At that time, the back gate of the palace was closed. Huo said:
Quickly open the back gate.
If it is opened, she will live. If not, she will die.
Dan ordered it to be opened, but she died before it could be opened.
By the third year of Yixi in the Jin dynasty, Nutan was defeated by Bubub, and the troops in Liangzhou were in chaos, and his whereabouts were unknown.
Shi Zong Shi Zong was a person of unknown origin.
He always wore hempen clothes, sometimesé‡ them to make coarse cloth, so the world called him the Daoist in hempen clothes.
His body had many sores and scabies, and his temperament was unstable.
He often stayed in the White Earth Cave in Guangling, singing for hire, and dancing to amuse himself, giving whatever he earned to others.
He had no fixed place to stay, sometimes hiding, sometimes appearing.
At that time, Gao Ping Tan Zhi was the magistrate of Jiangdu, and hearing about him, he summoned him.
His responses were quick and unconstrained, he was well-versed in ancient matters, and his discussions of the profound Confucian teachings were eloquent.
He then composed a poem, saying:
Having desires brings suffering and dissatisfaction, being desireless also brings no joy.
Not as good as the clear and empty one, wearing a belt and black robe.
Floating and wandering in the world, drifting like a boat without mooring.
Just about to end worldly entanglements, dwelling my mind in the mountains and hills.
Tan Zhi knew he was no ordinary person, and sent him back to his place.
He gave him thirty bolts of cloth, which he gave to beggars.
Later, there was a monk whose name was unknown, who always carried a staff and a box with him.
Once, he came to the magistrate of Haishang in the evening, saying:
I want to travel for several days. Can you temporarily lend me a person?
The magistrate said:
Take him as you wish.
He then selected the ugliest child among the guards of geese and ducks, and took him away.
In an instant, they arrived at a mountain. On the mountain, there was a house. In the house, there were three monks. They saw each other and happily talked together. The child did not understand.
At noon, he was tired. The monk asked the host for food on behalf of the child. He got a small bowl of food, which looked like cooked moxa. After eating it, the hunger stopped.
In the evening, the monk said goodbye and wanted to return.
He heard the people in the house asking:
Do you know where Shi Zong is?
When will his punishment end?ğŸ”½The monk said:
I don't know.
North of the Jiang River in Xuzhou, on the top of the white earth mound in Guangling, I have finished my exile.
The people in the house then wrote a letter, saying:
I entrust it to you.
The monk gave the letter to the boy.
By dawn, he arrived at the county and met with the magistrate, saying:
I want to stay here for a few days.
The magistrate said:
Very good.
He asked what was in the box, and the monk replied:
Just letters and documents.
The monk always slept on the office floor, with the box and staff at the head of the bed.
The magistrate sent someone to steal it at night and read it.
The monk already knew, and at dusk he always hung the box and staff high, lying down below, forever unobtainable.
Later, he took leave of the magistrate, saying:
I wanted to stay for a while, but you always wanted to steal it, so I'll just leave now.
The magistrate called the boy who had been there before and asked about the recent journey.
The boy said:
The Daoist master made him hold a staff, and he floated away, and they only heard the sound of waves under his feet.
He also said that the letter the mountain man entrusted to him was still in the child's clothing.
He told him to open it and look, but he didn't understand at all.
He then wrote down the letter and sealed it.
He sent the child to White Earth Hill and entrusted him to Shi Zong.
When Zong opened the letter, he was greatly surprised and said:
How did you get the letter from the Daoist master on Mount Penglai?
Later, Zong traveled south to Wu and Yue. Once, he passed by a fishing bridge and saw the fishermen catching a lot of fish. Zong then went upstream to wash, and the shoal of fish dispersed.
His secretly saving living beings was like this.
Later, he rested at Longshan Monastery in Shangyu.
He was good at discussing Zhuangzi and Laozi, and thoroughly understood the Analects and the Doctrine of the Mean, but he concealed his light and hid his traces, unknown to the world.
Xie Shao, Wei Mai, and Fang of Kuaiji all had profound discussions and studied under him.
Later, a monk who lived with Zong heard him talking with someone at night, perhaps about the events on Mount Penglai. At dawn, he did not know where Zong had gone.
Tao Yuanming's Record of Encountering Three Extraordinary Dharma Masters at the White Earth Cliff is one of them.
Some say that a merchant was traveling by sea and saw a monk on a deserted island, asking him to deliver a letter to Shi Zong.
He placed the letter on the boat, and his companions wanted to look at the letter, but the letter remained on the boat.
When they arrived at the White Earth Cliff, the letter flew up and went to Zong, who received it and took it away.
Bei Du Bei Du, whose name is unknown.
He always rode a wooden cup across the water, hence his name.
He was first seen in Jizhou.
He did not observe fine conduct, but his spiritual powers were outstanding, and the world did not know his origins.
Once, he stayed overnight in a family in the north. The family had a golden image, which Bei Du stole and took away.
The householder woke up and chased after him. He saw that he was walking slowly. He ran on horseback but could not catch up.
He reached the Mengjin River, floated a wooden cup on the water, and crossed the river by relying on it. Without relying on wind or oars, he was as light and fast as flying.
Suddenly, he reached the other shore and arrived in the capital city.
When seen, he was about forty years old, wearing a belt and tattered clothes, almost not covering his body.
His speech was erratic, and his joy and anger were inconsistent.
Sometimes he bathed in freezing cold water, sometimes he wore wooden clogs on the bed, and sometimes he walked barefoot in the market.
He only carried a reed basket, nothing else.
Sometimes he went to where the monk Fayi of Yanxian Temple was. Fayi prepared a separate room for him.
Later, he wanted to go to Yanbu River. At the river bank, he went to the ferry.
People told Du to not take him on board.
He then put his feet on the cup, looked around and hummed a tune. The cup naturally flowed straight to the north bank.
He was heading towards Guangling when he encountered a village where the Li family was holding an eight-part vegetarian feast.
They had never met before, yet he went straight into the hall and sat down, placing a straw basket in the middle of the courtyard.
The people there thought he was lowly and did not respect him.
Li saw the straw basket blocking the way and wanted to move it to the side of the wall, but several people could not lift it.
After the meal, he picked it up and left, laughing and saying:
The four heavenly kings are in the Li family.

At that time, a young boy peeked into the basket and saw four small children, each a few inches tall, with upright faces and bright clothes. He then chased after them but did not know where they were.
Three days later, he saw them sitting under a mulberry tree on the western border.
Li knelt and bowed, inviting them back to his home to make offerings for the month.
Du did not strictly observe the precepts, drinking alcohol, eating meat, and even consuming pungent and raw foods, no different from ordinary people.
The common people offered him things, which he sometimes accepted and sometimes did not.
Liu Xingbo of Pei State, as the governor of Yanzhou, sent an envoy to request him.
He came carrying a bundle of straw.
Xingbo had people lift it to look, and more than ten people could not lift it.
Bo looked at it himself and only saw a tattered robe and a wooden cup.
Later, he returned to Li's family and stayed for more than thirty days.
In the morning, he suddenly said:

Li immediately started to make it, but it was not finished by noon.
Du said he would go out for a while and did not return until dark.
The entire village smelled a strange fragrance, suspecting it was a ghost.
They searched everywhere for Du and found him lying dead under a northern cliff, with the tattered kÄá¹£Äya spread out on the ground.
Lotuses grew from his head and feet.
The flowers were extremely fresh and fragrant, but withered in one night.
The villagers buried him together.
A few days later, someone came from the north and said they saw Du carrying a straw bundle walking towards Pengcheng.
They opened the coffin together and only saw his shoes and socks.
When he arrived in Pengcheng, he met a layperson named Huang Xin who deeply believed in the Buddha-Dharma. Seeing that he was an arhat, he bowed in reverence and invited him to return home.
His family was extremely poor, only having wheat porridge.
Du accepted it with a happy and contented mind.
After staying for half a year, he suddenly told Xin:
Find thirty-six bundles of reeds for me to use.
Xin replied:
In this place, we can only have ten bundles. We are too poor to buy them, so we may not be able to prepare them all.
Du said:
You just search, there should be some in the house.
Xin searched thoroughly and found thirty-six bundles, lining them up in the courtyard.
Although there were that many, many of them were broken and damaged.
As Xin looked at them one by one, they were all new and complete.
Du sealed them up and told Xin to open them. He saw that they were all filled with money and silk, worth over a hundred thousand.

He went to Songjiang and floated a basin on the water, riding it to the other shore.
He traveled through Kuaiji and Shanxian, climbed Mount Tiantai, and returned to the capital after several months.
At that time, there was a foreign monk named Sengqie Zhe, who stayed at Changgan Temple in the capital.
There was a guest monk named Sengwu who shared a room with Zhe. Through a window, he saw Zhe take the temple's flagpole, hold it up into the clouds, and then lower it.
Sengwu did not dare to speak.

At that time, there was a person surnamed Zhang, named Nu, whose origins were unknown.
He did not eat much, but always had a full and pleasant appearance. He wore only single cotton clothes, regardless of the season.
When KÄtyÄyananandin was traveling, he saw Zhangnu and smiled happily.

Zhangnu then wrote on a locust tree and sang:
In the vast universe, the bright light truly shines.
Why are you confused and deluded, indulging in delusion and inviting misfortune?
The path of joy is rarely traveled, the path of suffering is like an overturned bag. Without the integrity of pine and cypress, how can one withstand wind and frost?
Far beyond the purple mist, singing long into the vast blue sky.
The pure spirit is beyond form, responding to the place of affinity.
The year shines on the empress of the Wei, the constellation graces the king of Yin.

Zhang Nu met with Bei Du and had a lot to say, which people did not understand.
Du still stayed in the capital for a short time, wandering without a fixed place. When invited, he sometimes went and sometimes did not.
At that time, there was a Chen family in Nanzhou who had some clothes and food. Du went to their family and was treated very well.

Hearing that there was another Bei Du in the capital, the five Chen family members all did not believe it. So they went to the capital to see him, and he was indeed like the Bei Du in their family, with the same appearance.
The Chen family prepared a bowl of honeyed ginger, a knife, frankincense, a handkerchief, and other things.
Du immediately ate all the honeyed ginger, and the other things were still in front of his knees.
The five Chen family members, fearing that he was the Bei Du in their family, kept two brothers in the capital to watch, while the remaining three returned home.
The cup-bearer in the family was as before, and there were also incense and a knife in front of his knees, but he did not eat honey and ginger, which was different.
He then said to Chen:
The knife is blunt, you can grind it for me.
The two younger brothers returned and said that the cup-bearer had already moved to Lingjiu Temple.
The cup-bearer in the family suddenly asked for two sheets of yellow paper to write a letter, the writing was illegible, and the back was the same.
Chen asked:
What kind of contract are you writing, Venerable?
The cup-bearer did not answer, and in the end, no one could understand the reason.
At that time, Zhu Lingqi, a citizen of Wujun, was on a mission to Gaoli. He encountered a storm at sea and drifted for nine days until he reached an island.
On the island, there was a mountain, and the mountain was very tall and large. He entered the mountain to collect firewood and saw a road.
Lingqi then followed the road with several people to beg for alms.
After walking for more than ten li, he heard the sound of a Buddhist service and the smell of incense smoke. They all chanted the Buddha's name and paid homage.
After a while, they saw a temple, very radiant and splendid, mostly adorned with the seven treasures.

They saw more than ten monks, all of whom were stone statues, motionless and unmoving. They then bowed together and walked back a little, hearing the sound of chanting and guidance. They went back to look again, but they were still stone statues.
Ling Qi and the others said to each other:
These are holy monks. We sinful people cannot see them.
They then sincerely repented together.
When they went again, they saw real people, who prepared food for Ling Qi and the others.
The food was vegetables, but the fragrance and deliciousness were unlike anything in the world.
After the meal, they all kowtowed and bowed, begging to quickly return home. A monk said:
From here to the capital, it is more than 200,000 li.
Just be sincere, don't worry about not being fast.
He then asked Ling Qi:
Do you know the monk Bei Du?
Ling Qi replied:
I know him very well.
He then pointed to a bag hanging on the northern wall, with a tin staff and alms bowl, saying:
This belongs to Bei Du. Now I will give you the bowl and let him have it.
And he wrote a letter and put it in the box.
There was also a green bamboo staff, and he said:
Just throw this staff into the water in front of the boat, close the boat and sit quietly, without needing to exert any effort, and it will surely reach quickly.
Then he took leave and sent a novice monk to see him off at the gate, saying:
Go this way, walk seven li and you will reach the boat, you don't need to take the previous road.
As instructed, he turned west and walked for about seven li to the boat, and it was exactly as he had shown.
He only heard the boat passing over the trees on the mountain peak, and did not see any water at all.
After three days, it reached Shi Tou Huai and stopped, and he no longer saw the bamboo staff.
The boat entered the Huai River and arrived at Zhuque Gate, where they saw Bei Du riding on a large boat railing, beating it with a staff, saying:
Why won't the horse go?
There were many onlookers.
Ling Qi and the others were in the boat, bowing to him from afar.
Du then got off the boat to retrieve the letter and bowl.
Opening the letter to look at it, the characters were unrecognizable to anyone.
Du laughed loudly, saying:
Why did you send me back?
He took the bowl and threw it into the clouds, then caught it again, saying:
I haven't seen this bowl in 4,000 years.
Du often stayed at Yanxian Temple with Fayi. At that time, people came to see the unusual bowl.
One story says:
Ling Qi's boat drifted to a remote mountain, where he encountered a monk who said:

This is the disciple of the ferryman. In the past, he held the master's bowl and died at the temple in the city. Now, using the master's bowl, he returns it to the master. Just have one person hold the bowl in front of the boat, and one person pull it straight. It will arrive safely.
As instructed, they indeed arrived safely.
At that time, Bei Du of the Southern State was on the railing of the boat on that day. He left early and did not return until late.
The Chen family saw blue writing on the door the next morning, with six characters saying:
The gate of blessings, a spiritual person has descended.
The characters were faint and barely recognizable. The family's Bei Du then disappeared without a trace.
Bei Du of the capital still went back and forth to the mountains and villages, often performing divine spells.
At that time, a maid of Yu Chang stole things and ran away. They chased her four times but did not capture her. They then asked Bei Du.
Bei Du said:
She has already died in an empty tomb by the river in Jincheng.
They went to look and found it was indeed as he said.
Kong Ningzi Shi was then the Chamberlain for Ceremonials, and was ill with diarrhea in the government office. He sent a message to invite Du to come.
Du finished chanting the spell and said:
It is difficult to cure.

Ningzi wept and said:
In the past, when Sun En rebelled, my family was destroyed by the soldiers. My parents and uncle were all brutally tortured.

There was also Qi Xie's wife, Lady Hu Mu, who was ill and many treatments did not cure her.

Qi Xie bowed to him as his teacher and wrote a biography for him, recording his divine and strange origins, which are largely the same as above.

In the third year of Yuanjia, in the ninth month, he took leave of Xie and entered the capital, leaving 10,000 coins and other things with Xie, asking him to hold a vegetarian feast. Then he departed.
He died of dysentery while traveling to Chishanshui Lake.
Xie immediately held a vegetarian feast and brought his body back to be buried on Fuzhou Mountain in Jianye.
In the fourth year, there was a man named Shao Xin of Wuxing who greatly revered the Dharma. He encountered a cold illness, and no one dared to attend to him. He then wept and contemplated Guanyin.
Suddenly he saw a monk come, saying he was a disciple of Bei Du.
He said:
Don't worry, your teacher will come soon to see you.
He replied:
Teacher Du has already passed away, how could he come?
The monk said:
What difficulty is there in coming?
He then took out a handful of powder from the head of his belt and gave it to him to take, and the illness immediately improved.
There was also a monk named Du Seng'ai who lived below Nan'gang. He had served Bei Du in the past.
His son was very seriously ill, and he thought regretfully that he could not get Du to chant divine spells.
The next day, he suddenly saw Du coming, speaking as usual, and immediately chanted the spell, and the patient was cured.
On the eighth day of the third month in the fifth year, Du came to Qi Xie's house again.
LÃ¼ Daohui, Yuren Tan, Du Tianqi, Shui Qiu Xi, and others all saw him together, and were greatly surprised. They immediately got up and paid homage to Du.
He said to the crowd:
This year will be greatly inauspicious, so diligently cultivate meritorious deeds.
The monk Fayi has great virtue. You can go to him to repair and establish the old temple to avert disasters and calamities.
In a moment, he heard a monk calling Du.
Du then took his leave, saying:
I will go to Jiao and Guang, and will not come back.
Qi Xie and the others respectfully saw him off, and then lost sight of him.
Later, there were also those who said they saw him, but since it was not definite, there is nothing to be transmitted.
Shi Tan Shi, a monk from Guanzhong.
Since his ordination, he had many extraordinary deeds.
At the end of the Daxuan era of Emperor Xiaowu of the Jin dynasty, he took dozens of sutras and vinaya texts to Liaodong to spread the teachings.
He expounded the Three Vehicles and established them in the precepts of returning to the origin. This was the beginning of Goguryeo's learning of the Way.
In the beginning of the Yixi era, he returned to Guanzhong and guided the people of the three capitals.
Shi's feet were white like his face. Even when walking barefoot through mud and water, they were never stained. Everyone called him the White-footed Venerable.
At that time, a man named Wang Hu in Chang'an, whose uncle had died several years ago, suddenly appeared and took Wang Hu around to the hells, showing him the various karmic retributions.
Hu wanted to return, and his uncle said to him:
Since you already know about cause and effect, you should just serve the white-footed arhat.
Hu searched for monks everywhere, and only saw Shi, whose feet were white like his face. He then served him.
At the end of the Jin dynasty, the Xiongnu tribe of the northern frontier, led by Helian Bobo,
overran Guanzhong, killing countless people.
At that time, Shi also encountered harm, but the sword could not injure him. Bobo marveled at this and granted a general amnesty to the monks, sparing their lives.
Shi then hid in the mountains and marshes, practicing the way of dhÅ«ta.
Later, Tuoba Tao again conquered Chang'an and became powerful in Guanzhong and Luoyang.
At that time, Cui Hao of Boling, who had studied left-path teachings since young, was jealous of Buddhism.
As he held a false position as an advisor, Tao relied on him. He then told Tao that Buddhism was useless and harmed the people's interests, advising him to abolish it.
Tao was deceived by his words and, in the seventh year of the false Taiping era, he destroyed Buddhism.
He dispatched troops to burn and plunder temples and monasteries, and ordered all monks and nuns to return to lay life.
Those who fled were all pursued and captured. If caught, they would be beheaded.
Within one realm, there are no more Å›ramaá¹‡as.
At first, it was only secluded and deep, inaccessible to the military.
By the end of the Taiping era, he began to know that the transformation was about to reach, and on the day of the Yuanhui, he suddenly arrived at the palace gate with his staff.
The officials reported:
There is a monk whose feet are whiter than his face, entering through the gate.
Tuo ordered him to be repeatedly cut down according to military law, but he was not injured.

He hurriedly reported this to Tuo, who became very angry and personally used his sword to strike him, but his body was no different, only the place where the sword touched had a mark like a thread of cloth.
At that time, tigers were raised in the northern garden in cages, and Tuo ordered Shi to feed them.
The tigers all hid and never dared to approach.
When the Celestial Master was tried and brought near the cage, the tigers immediately roared.

Tuo then knew that the Buddha's transformation was revered and lofty, and that the Yellow Emperor and Laozi could not reach it, so he invited Shi to the palace, bowed his head at his feet, and regretted his mistakes.
He began to expound the Dharma, clarifying cause and effect.
Tao was greatly ashamed and fearful, and eventually contracted a serious illness.
The two men Cui and Kou subsequently developed serious illnesses. Tao blamed the wrongdoing on them, and thus exterminated the two families, with all their members.
He proclaimed throughout the country to revive the correct teaching.
Soon after, Tao passed away, and his son Rui succeeded to the throne. He greatly promoted Buddhism, and its prosperity continues to this day.
It is unknown where he ended up after that.
Shi Flang, Shi Flang, was a person from Gaochang.
From a young age, he practiced with utmost sincerity and had many auspicious signs. He concealed his light and accumulated virtue, and no one could fathom his level.
Flang's teacher Shi Fajin was also a monk of high conduct.
Fajin once closed the door and sat alone, suddenly seeing Flang in front of him. He asked, Where did you come from?
He replied:
I came in through the door and lock.
He said:
You came with distant monks. Since it is almost noon, I wish you would prepare a meal.
Jin then prepared the meal, and they only heard the sound of spoons and bowls, but never saw any people.
In the past, Huiyuan of Mount Lu once sent a kÄá¹£Äya robe to Jin. Jin immediately gave it away as a gift.
Lang said:
The monks have already left. I will take it on another day.
Later, he saw the one in charge of cooking come to Jin to get the robe. Jin then gave it to him.
When he asked the usual person in charge of cooking, they all said they did not take it. He then realized that it was the sages who had taken it as a skillful means.
When the Wei barbarians destroyed the Buddhist Dharma, Lang went west to Kucha.
The king of Kucha made an agreement with the great meditation master of that country:
If there is anyone who has attained the Way and comes, you should tell me, and I will make offerings.
When Lang arrived, he reported it to the king, and the king treated him with the rites for a sage.
Later, he passed away in Kucha.
On the day of burning his body, the two eyebrows surged with springs, going straight up into the sky.
The crowd sighed in wonder and collected his bones to build a stÅ«pa.
Later, people from the Western Regions came to the northern region and fully transmitted this matter.
At that time, there was also a monk named Zhizheng in Liangzhou, who was also upright, austere, and had extraordinary conduct, and was revered by the ruler Yang Nandang.
Later, he entered the stone cave in Hanshi Mountain and did not return.
Shao She, whose original surname was Shao and given name was She, was a person from Shikang.
He had no fixed residence, was confused and erratic like a madman, had a big mouth, and had ugly eyebrows and eyes.
Children liked to chase after him and play with him.
Sometimes he would enter a wine shop and drink with others.
But he loved Buddhism and whenever he saw an image, he would pay homage, praise it, and weep with emotion.
Shao originally had three sons and two daughters. The eldest son, Huisheng, also became a monk.
Shao also became a monk in the early years of the Song Dynasty and called himself Shao Gong.
He came and went without distinguishing between day and night.
He traveled to various counties in Yizhou and went to the barbarian areas, always speaking in a way that suited the situation, using humor to encourage goodness.
If he slept on the ground in someone's home, someone in that family would die.
If he begged for a fine mat from someone, a child in that family would die. At the time, people all took this as an omen.
On the eighth day of the fourth month, when the image procession was held in Chengdu, Shi made himself crawl in the crowd, acting like a lion.
On that day, the counties also said they saw Shi acting like a lion, so they realized he had manifested in multiple places.
The Prefect Xiao Huikai and Liu Mengming and others all revered and served him.
Mengming dressed his two concubines in men's clothing and tested Shi, saying:
Can you take these two people to serve you as your left and right?
Shi, who liked to speak in rhyme, said to Mengming:
I would rather beg for wine to soak and swallow it, than spend the rest of my years with these two women.
One day, Shi suddenly put on a cloth hat and went to Mengming.
After a short while, Meng Ming died.
Previously, Shen Zhongyu, the Prefectural Historian, changed the rules for whipping and beating, making them more severe than the usual regulations.
Shuo said to Yu:
From this point on, the world will be in chaos. If you remove the whipping rules, you will become the Prefect.
Yu believed him and removed the rules.
When Meng Ming died, Zhongyu indeed took over the prefectural affairs.
On the first day of the ninth month of the first year of the Yuanhui era of the Song dynasty, he died at Tongyun Temple in Mount Min.
Before his death, he told the monk Fa Jin:
Expose my body and quickly tie my shoes to my feet.
Afterwards, they did as he said and took the corpse to the back of the temple.
After two days, they could not find it.
Soon, someone came from Pixian and passed by Jin, saying:
Yesterday I saw Master Shuo in the market, with one foot in a shoe, rambling and saying:
'Young man, it's not appropriate to go out without a pair of shoes.'
The monk was startled and questioned the novice, who replied:
Recently, when sending out the corpse, I was frightened and could not tie my right shoe well, so I lost it.
His traces were strange and inexplicable.
Later, it was unknown where he ended up.
Shi Huian, Shi Huian, it is unknown which place he was from.
When he was young, he was captured and became a slave of a person from Jingzhou. He worked diligently and his master loved him very much.
At the age of eighteen, he was allowed to go forth and stayed at Pipa Temple in Jiangling.
His appearance was ordinary and people often looked down on him.
At that time, he was a novice monk. When the monks were seated in rows, he was always made to distribute water.
An always held an empty bottle and went from top to bottom, and the water was always not exhausted.
At that time, everyone considered it strange.
After receiving full ordination, he gradually displayed spiritual traces.

Once, on the evening of the thirtieth day of the month, he was together with his fellow student Huiji in the hall for the poá¹£adha ceremony. The hall door had not yet been opened, but An wove his fingers through the cracks in the wall and entered. When leaving, he did the same.
Huiji was greatly startled and afraid, not daring to speak.
Later, he was together with Huiji sitting under a pagoda, and then spoke to Huiji, saying:
I am going to travel far, and now I take leave of you.
Soon, he saw heavenly beings, music, incense, and flowers filling the sky.
Huiji was only frightened and terrified, and in the end, he could not speak.
An again said to him:
You must be careful not to speak recklessly about the events I have experienced before, for speaking of them will certainly bring misfortune.
Only to a layperson in the southwest who is a newly enlightened bodhisattva can you fully speak of them.
Thereupon, he took leave and immediately joined a merchant caravan to enter Xiang and Chuan.
On the way, he became extremely ill with dysentery, and said to the boatman:
My life will certainly come to an end, but just take me out and place me on the shore, you need not use a vessel or wood.
After the breath is cut off, immediately give it to insects and birds.
The merchants followed his words and laid him on the shore.
At night, they saw flames coming out from his body. The merchants were surprised and frightened, and when they went to look, he had already died.
The merchants traveled to Xiangdong, where they saw An had already arrived earlier, but they soon lost track of him.
Ji later arrived at Zhiqi Temple and visited the recluse Liu Qiong of Nanyang, telling him in detail about the incident.
Qiong immediately stood up and bowed from afar to Ji, saying:
This is a person who has attained the Way and has entered the samadhi of firelight.
At that time, there were also Seng Lan and Fa Wei in Shu, who both had extraordinary traces. People of the time also suspected that they had attained the fruit of sagehood.
Shi Fa Kui, originally surnamed Rui, was a person from Wuxing Yuzhong.
He left home at a young age and became a disciple of Fa Kai of Zhiyuan Temple in the capital.
Kai had studied diligently and was particularly skilled in scriptures and history. Wang Huan and Wang Su of Langya both studied under him.
Kai was by nature respectful and taciturn, speaking little. He was simple and self-reliant, not engaging in human affairs.
He recited the Lotus Sutra in its entirety.
The elder Dusheng of the temple was old and sick, so Kai served as his attendant, caring for him with utmost devotion.
When Dusheng passed away, he gave him a proper burial.
Whenever he received money at the vegetarian feasts, he saved it to make a sandalwood statue.
When the statue was completed, he held a grand assembly himself.
His original family lived in the capital's large market. He returned home in the morning, then went to Dinglin, and again returned to Zhiyuan.
Later, the three places checked and found that Kai had come to eat at noon in all three places. He truly went to three places at the same time.
That day, he returned to his room in the evening, and suddenly passed away while lying down.
His body was very fragrant and soft, with two fingers curled up.
The assembly all realized that he had attained the two fruits.
At that time, he was still a novice monk, but his spiritual traces were extraordinary, and he eventually became known to Emperor Wu.
The emperor personally visited and held a vegetarian feast for the monks.
Wenhui and Wenxuan both went to his room to pay homage and arranged for his funeral.
The common people flocked to the scene, and donations were made in abundance.
He then used the offerings he received to build a pagoda at Zhiyuan Temple.
This was in the seventh year of the Yongming era of the Qi dynasty.
Shi Senghui, Shi Senghui, whose surname was Liu, was not known where he was from.
He stayed in Jingzhou for several decades.
Liu Qiu of Nanyang established Zhiqi Temple and invited him to reside there.
At that time, people had seen him for fifty or sixty years, but he never aged.
His behavior was hurried, and he did not have much etiquette.
When he went to the homes of sick people, if he was angry, they would definitely die, and if he was happy, they would definitely recover. At that time, everyone used this as a prophecy.
Those who had not met him before all knew their relatives' survival or death.
Hui once went to the riverbank and told the ferryman to take him across.
The ferryman insisted that the boat was small and could not take him across.
But in an instant, Hui was already on the other side. Everyone on both banks marveled at his supernatural abilities.
Zhen Tian of Zhongshan and Che Tan of Nanping both invited Hui on the same day.
Hui went to both places.
Later, when the two families checked, they realized that Hui had manifested in two places at once.
In the Yongming period of the Qi dynasty, Wen Hui was going down to the capital and passed by Bao Ji on the way.
Ji patted his back and said:
You are a child of the red dragon.
He did not say anything else.
Later, Hui returned to Jingzhou and suddenly saw Liu Jingrui, the governor of Zhenxi, and wept bitterly, throwing himself at Jingrui's feet.
After a few days, Jingrui was indeed killed by the governor.
Later, when Hui arrived south of the Xiangzhou city, he suddenly said that there was a stele in the ground.
The people tried digging and indeed found two of them.
Later, it is unknown where Hui died.
Some say he died in Jiangling during the Yongyuan period.

Tong later went to Jiangling himself, but Huixu had already died.
Entering her room, he inquired in detail and stayed in Jiangling for a while.
Passing by people's homes and graves, he knew their surnames, clans, deaths, and the year and month without fail.
He told them what he knew, and it was all as he said.
Sometimes he would point out thieves and robbers, describing their crimes. Then, when the group of thieves saw someone coming, they would avoid him from afar.
Again, on the road to Jiangjin, he encountered a person and suddenly hit him with his staff, saying:
You should quickly return home and see what happens to your family.
This person arrived home and found that his house was indeed affected by a spreading fire, and all the property in the house was completely burned.
In the Yongyuan era of the Qi dynasty, he suddenly went to an acquaintance named Ren Yang, urgently asking for wine, saying:
Now I should go far away and will not see you again.
For me, apologize to all my acquaintances, and everyone should diligently cultivate goodness first.
After drinking the wine, he lay down on the ground by the wall.
When they went to check on him, he was already dead.
Later, in a few dozen days, someone saw him again in the market.
They chased after him and talked together for a long time before losing sight of him.
Shi Baizhi Shi Baizhi, originally surnamed Zhu, was a person from Jincheng.
He left home at an early age and stayed at Daolin Temple in the capital, serving the Å›ramaá¹‡a Sengjian as his preceptor, practicing meditation.

In the first year of Taishi in the Song dynasty, he suddenly became eccentric, staying in no fixed place, eating and sleeping at irregular times, with long hair several inches long, always walking barefoot in the streets, carrying a tin staff, hanging scissors and a mirror on the top of the staff, or hanging one or two pieces of silk.

He did not eat for several days, but had no expression of hunger.
When speaking with people, it was initially difficult to understand, but later it was all effective.

The common people of the capital all served him.
Emperor Wu of the Qi dynasty said he confused the masses and arrested him in Jiankang.
The next morning, people saw him entering the market.
When they checked the prison again, Zhi was still there.
Zhi said to the prison officer:

Yet, on Mount Jingyang, there was still one Zhi, together with seven monks.

Zhi has long since left and is now smearing ink on his body.

Zhizhi said:
Being at your disposal tomorrow means the corpse will be taken out tomorrow.
When Sima Yinqi of the Eastern Wei Dynasty was stationed in Jiangzhou with Chen Xianshi, he took leave of Zhi.
Zhi drew a tree on paper, with a crow on it, and said:

When Sang Yan, the Cavalry Commander of the Qi Dynasty, was about to plot a rebellion, he went to see Zhi.
Zhi saw him from afar and ran away, shouting loudly:
Surrounding the capital city, wanting to rebel, chopping off the head and breaking the belly.
After less than ten days, the incident broke out.
Yan rebelled and went to Zhu Fang, where he was captured by others. Sure enough, his head was chopped off and his belly broken open.
The Liang Prince of Poyang, who was loyal and valiant, once invited Zhizhe to come to his residence.
Suddenly he ordered someone to search for a thorny plant urgently. After obtaining it, he placed it on the gate, but no one knew the reason.

His premonitions and insights were of this kind, not just one instance.

Zhizhe's traces are constrained by dust and defilements, but his spirit roams in the profound and tranquil. Water and fire cannot scorch or moisten him, and snakes and tigers cannot harm or frighten him.
If one speaks of his Buddhist principles, he is above the stage of the hearers;
if one discusses his hidden abilities, he is higher than the transcendent immortals.
How can one restrict him with the ordinary feelings of a secular person? How narrow-minded and petty can one be to this extent?
From now on, let him come and go as he pleases, without further restrictions.
From then on, Huiji often entered and left the palace.

I wish to pray for rain by lecturing on the ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ-sÅ«tra in Huaguang Hall.

Huiji also said:
We need a basin of water with a knife on top of it.
Soon after, it rained heavily, and the rain was sufficient everywhere.

I have not yet eliminated afflictions and delusions. How can I treat them?
He replied:
Twelve.
Those who knew him

Later, Fayun lectured on the Lotus Sutra at Hualin Temple, and when he reached even if a black wind,

The emperor sighed:

He then provided generous funeral services and buried him on the solitary dragon mound of Zhong Mountain.
He also established Kaishan Monastery at the burial site.
He ordered Lu Xie to compose a stele inscription inside the tomb, and Wang Yun to write a stele text at the temple gate.
His legacy and image are preserved everywhere.
At the beginning of his life, his appearance was that of a man in his fifties or sixties, and at the end, he did not age either. People could not fathom his age.

At that time, in the early years of the Liang dynasty, there were also Dao Xiang and Seng Lang in Shu, who were also said to possess spiritual powers.
The treatise says:
The transformation of the spiritual way is to suppress arrogance and strength, to destroy contempt and pride, to blunt the sharpness of the violent, and to unravel the dust and confusion.

One should know that the ultimate governance is without intention, and the firmness and flexibility are in the transformation.
